name: curry

parameters.name: f
parameters.description: is a function to be curried

returnValue.description: a curried version of an f function

examples: import { curry } from "@commonly/function"const power = curry(Math.pow)power(2)(3)     // -> 8
description: Preforms a {@link https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Currying | currying} of an f function.

name: debounce

parameters.name: debounced
parameters.description: is a function to be debounced

parameters.name: wait
parameters.description: is a time in milliseconds to delay the next execution of the debounced function

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: is an object which further defines the behaviour of the debounced function

examples: import { debounce } from "@commonly/function"document.body.onscroll = debounce(alert, 25)     // -> A prompt will be shown only once for every time scrolling happens

name: empty

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: is an object to be emptied

returnValue.description: an empty object of that type

examples: import { empty } from "@commonly/function"empty([ 1, 1, 2 ])           // -> []empty("112")                 // -> ""empty({ x: 1, y: 1, z: 2 })  // -> {}
description: Creates an empty value of the same type as the one passed in.

name: identity
examples: import { identity } from "@commonly/function"identity(2)     // -> 2identity(3)     // -> 3identity(5)     // -> 5
description: In mathematics, an identity function, also called an identity relation or identity map or identity transformation, is a function that always returns the same value that was used as its argument. That is, for f being identity the equality f(x) = x holds for all x.

name: negate

parameters.name: predicate
parameters.description: is a predicate function to be negated

returnValue.description: a negated version of a predicate function

examples: import { negate } from "@commonly/function"const isUnsealed = negate(Object.isSealed)isUnsealed(window)  // -> true
description: Negates a given {@link @commonly/type:Primitive | predicate function}, thus creating a new negated version of that function.

name: noop

parameters.description: is a variadic list of parameters which are unused anyway

description: Always returns an undefined no matter the arguments.

name: partial

parameters.name: f
parameters.description: is a function to partially apply list of arguments to

parameters.name: applied
parameters.description: is a list of arguments to be prepended to an f function

examples: import { partial } from "@commonly/function"const isNaN = partial(Object.is, NaN)isNaN(NaN)  // -> true
description: Partially applies a list of arguments to an f function. It's similar to a {@link https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Function/bind | Function.prototype.bind} method, except it preserves *this* context.

name: reducer
description: Provides a reducing function based on passed in accumulator, if nothing suitable is found, then it returns an identity function.

name: tap

parameters.name: interceptor
parameters.description: is a function to which the intercepted value will be provided, any value returned will be thrown away

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: is a value to be intercepted

examples: import { tap } from "@commonly/function"Promise.resolve(3).then(tap(alert))    // -> value `x` will be shown in the alert box, it will equal to 3.then(x => x * x)    // -> x is still equal to 3, chain is preserved.then(tap(alert))    // -> value `x` will be shown again, this time it will equal to 9
description: Invokes a function on a given value and returns that value.

name: throttle

parameters.name: throttled
parameters.description: is a function to be throttled

parameters.name: wait
parameters.description: is a time in milliseconds to delay the next execution of the throttled function

examples: import { throttle } from "@commonly/function"document.body.onscroll = throttle(alert, 1250)     // -> A prompt will be shown once every 1250 milliseconds
